docs.lead_paragraph: I am practically giddy as I write this. I am seated at my regular coffee shop, the one where I came nearly every morning to work until about five weeks ago, when a bad fall more or less confined me to the couch. But broken bones heal, and while I am still on crutches, and not yet allowed to put weight on my left foot, I am now wearing jeans (rather than the yoga pants I wore for five weeks), with a shoe on my right foot (rather than a sneaker). Most exhilarating of all, I drove here on my own. For the first time in more than a month, I feel like ME.

docs.lead_paragraph: SPERO--James Sterling, 84, of Kendal at Ithaca, NY passed away Thursday, March 31, at Cayuga Medical Center after a cardiac arrest. Born August 26, 1926 in New York, NY, he was the son of Sterling D. Spero and Louise Rothschild Spero. He attended elementary and high school at the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University in New York City where he met Cecile H. Schiffer. They were married in 1948 and lived happily until his passing. Jim attended undergraduate school as part of the Navy V-12 program at Wesleyan University and Yale University. He received an Honorable Discharge from the U.S. Navy in 1946 and was a Commissioned Ensign, U.S. Naval Reserve in 1947. He received a BA in Sociology from Yale University in 1947 and an MS in Rural Sociology at the University of Wisconsin in 1950. Jim spent his career working for Cornell Cooperative Extension, first as Count 4-H Agent in Orange County, NY and then as Senior Extension Associate, working with Cornell faculty and administrative staff on campus, in New York City, and other metropolitan areas of the state on nutrition education, urban gardening, consumer education and housing programs. He was actively involved in volunteer work with the United Way, the Tompkins County Mental Health Board, HOMES Inc. and Family and Children's Service of Ithaca. He was also appointed to the Kendal at Ithaca Board of Trustees in 2005. In 2009, Family and Children's Service of Ithaca created the Spero Family Fund for Child Psychiatry to honor Jim and Ceil for their loyal and dedicated support in advancing mental health initiatives, in children's mental health and psychiatry. In November, 2010 Jim and Ceil were chosen as Philanthropists of the Year by the Association of Fundraising Professionals, New York Finger Lakes Chapter. They have made significant gifts that transformed services and lives. Jim particularly enjoyed spending time at their cottage on Cayuga Lake with family and friends. He was a truly unforgettable man who knew how to live life fully with integrity and joy. His love for his family, great sense of humor and practical mind helped everyone around him through good times and bad. He was predeceased by his daughter Jean Spero and his brother Robert Spero. In addition to his wife, Ceil, he is survived by his children: Bette Spero of Buffalo, NY, Donald Spero (Julie Cooper) of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Nancy Spero (Rob Sullivan) of Ithaca, NY; his grandchildren Susannah Spero and Samuel Spero; his sister Ellen Roman, his sisters-in-law Miriam Spero and Herma Shore; his first cousin Richard Cohn; his six nieces and nephews; his eight grand nieces and nephews; and many special friends. There will be no calling hours. Friends are invited to attend a celebration of his life at Kendal at Ithaca on Saturday, April 23, 2011 at 2pm. Memorial contributions may be made to "The Spero Family Fund for Child Psychiatry" at Family & Children's Service, 127 West State Street, Ithaca, NY 14850 and Kendal at Ithaca (for the Rainy Day Fund), 2230 N. Triphammer Rd., Ithaca, NY 14850. Contact Bangs Funeral Home, 607-272-1922 for more information.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last year the N.H.L. general managers acknowledged that something was wrong about the shootout, the postgame penalty-shot contest it installed in 2005, when it abolished tie results. They ruled that this season, shootout wins would be thrown out if teams were tied in the standings, and it was under that proviso that the Rangers entered their last game behind Carolina in the race for the final Eastern playoff spot. They had the same number of points, but the Hurricanes were ahead because they had more nonshootout victories.

headline.main: N.H.L. Math Often Equals Points for All

docs.abstract: Slap Shot blog examines debate in NHL over the impact of overtime shootouts on points standings; other items noted. Photo (M)

docs.abstract: Despite the distaste it generates among hockey executives, the regular-season shootout is here to stay. Purists, at least, are comforted by the lack of support for installing shootouts in the playoffs.
